TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM
 BRONCHOSCOPY - At [**2167-6-10**] 01:53 AM
   - Admitted to MICU
   - Bronch done with large amount of yellow sputum throughout left
   airways but no obstructing lesions.
   - Unable to place A-line
   - Increased PEEP, decreased FiO2, and decreased Vt overnight
   - SBP decreased to 80s (MAP 65) with normalization of lactate but
   decreased UOP 25cc/h. Given 500cc bolus x 2 and propofol decreased with
   improvement in SBP to 90s and MAP >65 but no change in UOP.
   --
   Collateral info: Per b/f, PCP is [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]. Pt with h/o bipolar
   disorder and had been very awake for 4-5 days. On Monday, b/f unable to
   arouse her from sleep. Still sleeping when returned from work. Tuesday
   AM, still unable to wake her. Noted urinary incontinence so called EMS.
   No observed tonic clonic movements or bowel incontinence; no h/o
   seizure d/o. Concern for overdose given empty pill bottles found near
   her. Per b/f, pt overdosed 8-9 years ago. Did not convey recent SI but
   multiple stressors recently including ongoing psych med adjustments,
   CCY several weeks ago, and arguments with parents and b/f. No fevers,
   change in chronic cough, or SOB per b/f. PMH notable for bipolar
   disorder, thyroid disorder (unclear if taking meds), and EtOH
   neuropathy. SH notable for 1.5 ppd x 25 years, h/o EtOH abuse but none
   in [**5-11**] years. H/o cocaine 10 years ago; no h/o IVDU. ROS notable for
   some leg edema s/p CCY. NKDA. FH: Mother with CHF. SH: Lives with
   long-time boyfriend; was phlebotomist in past.

[**2167-6-10**] 1:08 am SPUTUM      Source: Endotracheal.

      >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.
      3+  (5-10 per 1000X FIELD):   MULTIPLE ORGANISMS CONSISTENT WITH
                                    OROPHARYNGEAL FLORA.
   RESPIRATORY CULTURE (Preliminary):
   [**2167-6-10**] Urine legionella Ag pending
   [**2167-6-9**] Bcx NGTD x 2
   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o unclear psych history and reported hypothyroidism
   who presented to OSH with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory
   failure requiring intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left
   lung atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Likely CAP v. aspiration although unknown whether pt with risk factors
   for HAP.  Favor broad antibiotic coverage at this time pending further
   micro and clinical history data.
   - Vancomycin, zosyn for empiric coverage of HAP and aspiration pna;
   Levofloxacin for empiric coverage
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures, urine legionella
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily RSBI/SBT
   - Wean sedation as tolerated
   - Not ARDS as unilateral but given P/F <200, absence of CHF will aim
   for Vt 4-6 mg/kg, uptitrate PEEP prn with caution given unilateral
   - Obtain medical history from PCP
   .
   # Hypotension: Concern for sepsis in setting of pneumonia. U/A u
   # Elevated lactate: Anion gap 13. Likely elevated lactate in setting of
   hypoperfusion. [**Month (only) 11**] have had decreased po intake recently in setting of
   acute illness although also concern for sepsis given above findings.
   Currently maintaing MAP >60.
   - Trend lactate
   - IV fluid hydration
   - Goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   - Abx as above
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Moderate sized on CT chest. No pulsus
   paradoxicus on exam (8).
   - TTE in AM to evaluate
   .
   # ?Hypothyroidism: Per OSH report, unclear history and no levothyroxine
   in med bag
   - Check TSH
   - Clarify with PCP in AM
   .
   # Increased lethargy: Presenting complaint to OSH. Unclear psych
   history. Also question of seizure disorder given the meds with her.
   - Reassess neuro status as wean sedation
   - Hold topiramate and divalproex for now; seizure precautions
   - Hold seroquel, clonazepam, and provigil for now
   - Clarify with PCP in AM
   .
   # Insomnia: On zolpidem prn as outpatient. Holding for now.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: OGT awaiting placement confirmation, nutrition c/s for tube
   feeds
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2167-6-9**] 11:59 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ heparin, pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: H2B
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Boyfriend [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 7171**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7172**] H,
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7173**]. Father [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 1247**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7174**] (currently fighting;
   mother in hospital). Sister [**Name (NI) 1298**] in [**Name (NI) 122**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7175**] H, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7176**]
   C. Also has 4 stepbrothers.. Psychiatrist [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) 3743**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 7166**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7167**].
   Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] from [**Hospital1 49**] ([**Hospital 7177**] Clinic).

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the MICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. She has a history of bipolar disorder, thyroid disorder, and EtOH neuropathy. She was found to have a left lung collapse, likely secondary to mucous plugging from extensive consolidative pneumonia. The patient was started on empiric antibiotic coverage for HAP and aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 87/59 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and she is receiving oxygen therapy via an endotracheal tube.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 214 K/uL. Her lactate level is elevated at 1.1 mmol/L, and her anion gap is 13. The patient's blood cultures are pending, and her sputum Gram stain shows >25 polymorphonuclear cells and <10 epithelial cells per 100X field, consistent with oropharyngeal flora.

The patient's medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, and her medication list includes psychotropic medications such as topiramate, divalproex, seroquel, and clonazepam. She has a history of EtOH abuse and has been experiencing increased lethargy and insomnia.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's left lung collapse and consolidative pneumonia may lead to further respiratory decline if not adequately managed.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and anion gap suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiovascular status.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's unclear history of hypothyroidism and lack of levothyroxine in her medication bag may indicate a need for further evaluation and treatment.
4. Seizure disorder: The patient's history of psychotropic medication use and unclear seizure disorder diagnosis may indicate a need for further evaluation and treatment.
5. Insomnia: The patient's history of insomnia and current sedation may lead to further sleep disturbances and potential delirium.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Respiratory support: Weaning of ventilator as tolerated with daily RSBI/SBT.
2. Antibiotic therapy: Empiric coverage for HAP and aspiration pneumonia with vancomycin, zosyn, and levofloxacin.
3. Cardiovascular support: Maintenance of MAP >60, IV fluid hydration, and goal UOP >30 cc/h.
4. Neurological evaluation: Reassessment of neuro status as wean sedation, and clarification of unclear psych history.
5. Thyroid evaluation: Check TSH and clarify with PCP in the morning.
6. Insomnia management: Holding of zolpidem and reassessment of sleep disturbances.

The patient's family has been notified, and the patient's code status is presumed full. The patient's disposition is still pending further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was intubated and found to have left lung collapse with extensive consolidative pneumonia. The patient has a history of unclear psychiatric history, hypothyroidism, and reports of bipolar disorder and EtOH neuropathy.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F)
* Heart rate: 80 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 87/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.3 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 214 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 15 mg/dL
* Sodium: 142 mEq/L
* Potassium: 3.6 mEq/L
* Chloride: 109 mEq/L
* Glucose: 122 mg/dL

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
* Vt (Set): 360 mL
* RR (Set): 16
* PEEP: 10 cmH2O
* FiO2: 60%

The patient's physical examination shows:

* General: No acute distress, intubated and sedated
* HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear, +ETT, +OGT
* Neck: Supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD
* Lungs: Bronchial breath sounds b/l, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi
* CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops
* Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly
* GU: Foley
* Ext: Extremities mildly cool, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis: Given the patient's pneumonia and elevated lactate levels, sepsis is a potential complication.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism and unclear medication list may lead to hypothyroidism-related complications.
* Overdose: The patient's positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone may indicate an overdose, which could lead to respiratory depression and other complications.
* Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may progress and lead to further respiratory complications.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's moderate-sized pericardial effusion may lead to cardiac complications if not properly managed.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Broad antibiotic coverage for pneumonia
* Weaning of sedation and respiratory support
* Monitoring of lactate levels and urine output
* Consideration of switching to fentanyl/versed for persistent hypotension
* Evaluation of pericardial effusion with a transesophageal echocardiogram
* Clarification of the patient's medication list and restart of home medications
* Reassessment of neuro status as sedation is weaned.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female admitted to the MICU with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. She has a history of bipolar disorder, thyroid disorder, and ethanol abuse. The patient's presentation is concerning for possible overdose, given the empty pill bottles found near her. She has been unresponsive for several days, with a recent decrease in PO intake and no improvement in her condition.

The patient's laboratory results show signs of sepsis, with elevated lactate levels and anion gap. The respiratory culture is pending, but the Gram stain suggests oropharyngeal flora. The patient has a moderate-sized pericardial effusion on CT chest and is being evaluated for possible hypothyroidism.

The patient's medications include propofol, vancomycin, and Zosyn for empiric coverage of HAP and aspiration pneumonia. She is being weaned from sedation and ventilator support as tolerated.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and anion gap suggest sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not addressed promptly.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further hypoxia and hypercapnia.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's unclear history and lack of levothyroxine in her medication bag suggest the possibility of hypothyroidism, which can lead to a range of symptoms and complications if left untreated.
4. Pericardial Effusion: The patient's moderate-sized pericardial effusion on CT chest may require further evaluation and management to prevent cardiac tamponade.
5. Overdose: The patient's history of overdose and recent stressors may increase her risk of overdose, which can lead to serious complications and even death.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of seizure disorder and unclear psych history may increase her risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or altered mental status.
7. Infection: The patient's respiratory culture is pending, but the Gram stain suggests oropharyngeal flora. Further evaluation and management are necessary to prevent and treat any potential infections.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's decreased PO intake and lack of nutrition may lead to malnutrition, which can exacerbate her underlying medical conditions and increase her risk of complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 43-year-old female, was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, left lung collapse, and unclear psych history. She presented to the hospital with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient has been receiving invasive ventilation and has undergone a bronchoscopy, which showed a lot of sputum but no evidence of airway obstruction.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 87/59 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 100% on 60% FiO2. The patient is receiving propofol infusion and has a moderate-sized pericardial effusion on CT chest.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, an elevated lactate level, and abnormal electrolyte levels. The respiratory culture is pending, and the patient is being treated empirically with vancomycin, zosyn, and levofloxacin.

The patient's medical history is unclear, and her past medical history is unknown. She has a reported history of hypothyroidism, but her current thyroid status is unknown. The patient's medication list includes topiramate, divalproex, seroquel, clonazepam, and provigil, which may be related to her increased lethargy and potential seizure disorder.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia complicated by mucus plugging, which may lead to further lung collapse and respiratory failure.
2. Aspiration event, which may lead to anaerobic infections and sepsis.
3. Tracheal obstruction, which may lead to post-obstructive pneumonia and respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis, which may lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
5. Hypothyroidism, which may worsen the patient's respiratory and cardiac status.
6. Pericardial effusion, which may lead to cardiac tamponade and death.
7. Seizure disorder, which may worsen the patient's respiratory and cardiac status.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue invasive ventilation and wean as tolerated.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
3. Treat the patient empirically with broad-spectrum antibiotics and adjust based on culture results.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's lactate level and adjust fluid hydration and vasopressor therapy as necessary.
6. Consider performing a tracheostomy to improve ventilation and reduce the risk of tracheal obstruction.
7. Consider performing a thyroid function test to determine the patient's current thyroid status and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist and an intensivist to optimize the patient's respiratory and cardiac care.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old woman with a significant psychiatric history, including prior drug overdose, who was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was found somnolent by her boyfriend and brought to the emergency department. She has been receiving mechanical ventilation and has been stable overnight. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, and blood pressure of 87/59 mmHg. She has a pericardial effusion noted on CT scan, and her laboratory results show an elevated lactate level and abnormal liver function tests.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to being intubated for an extended period and receiving mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and abnormal liver function tests suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or pericarditis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's pericardial effusion and abnormal liver function tests may indicate cardiac compromise, which could lead to cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to the development of respiratory muscle weakness, which could lead to respiratory arrest.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's obtundation and abnormal liver function tests may indicate neurological compromise, which could lead to seizures, coma, or other neurological deficits.
6. Infection control issues: The patient's polymicrobial Gm stain on sputum culture suggests the possibility of infection, which could lead to the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's pericardial effusion and abnormal liver function tests may indicate gastrointestinal compromise, which could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or other complications.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 43-year-old woman with a history of psychiatric issues, including drug overdose, was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was found somnolent by her boyfriend and brought to the hospital. Overnight, she underwent bronchoscopy without airway obstruction, and 2.5L of IV fluids were administered for marginal urine output and hypotension, which was fluid-responsive.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 87/59 mmHg. She is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 360 mL and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Her SpO2 is 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.3 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 31.7%
* Platelet count: 214 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

Imaging studies reveal a left lower lobe collapse with lingular and left upper lobe infiltrate, as well as a pericardial effusion.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure: likely community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) versus hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) versus aspiration with mucous plugging. She will be weaned off sedation and a pressure support ventilation (PSV) trial will be performed.
* Possible sepsis: hypotensive with elevated lactate overnight, fluid-responsive. She will receive broad antibiotic coverage with vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin, which will be narrowed in 48 hours based on CX data.
* Pericardial effusion: noted on CT scan, no evidence of pulsus on exam. An echocardiogram will be performed today.
* Obtundation: polypharmacy noted on history, history of overdose, hypothyroidism, and unclear compliance. Her TSH level will be checked today, and her psych regimen will be clarified with her primary psychiatrist.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis: the patient's hypotensive response to fluid resuscitation and elevated lactate levels overnight suggest a possible sepsis.
* Pneumonia: the patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure and radiological findings are consistent with pneumonia.
* Pericardial effusion: the patient's pericardial effusion may require further evaluation and management.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: the patient's history of overdose and polypharmacy may increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Respiratory failure: the patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly.
* Infection: the patient's polymicrobial Gm stain on sputum and pending blood and urine cultures may indicate a polymicrobial infection.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch, 59.1 kg individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of respiratory failure, acute, and pericardial effusion without tamponade. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder and is currently on outpatient medications. The patient's 24-hour events include a trans-thoracic echo showing a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade, and the patient was restarted on their outpatient medications. The patient continues to be unable to follow commands when propofol is weaned off.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure of 95/65 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 12 inspirations per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 11.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 214 K/uL. The patient's blood urea nitrogen is 15 mg/dL, and creatinine is 0.7 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of worsening respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying condition.
2. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion is not causing tamponade, but there is a risk of worsening or developing cardiac tamponade if the effusion increases in size.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is slightly low, which may indicate a risk of hypotension or shock if not monitored and managed properly.
4. Seizures: Although the patient's psychiatrist confirmed that the patient does not have a diagnosis of seizures, there is still a risk of seizures due to the patient's underlying condition and the use of sedatives such as propofol.
5. Infection: The patient's white blood cell count is slightly elevated, which may indicate a risk of infection. The patient's antibiotic regimen should be closely monitored and adjusted as necessary.
6. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is slightly positive, which may indicate a risk of fluid overload. The patient's fluid status should be closely monitored and managed to prevent fluid overload.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is recommended that the patient continue to be closely monitored and managed in the ICU with adjustments to their respiratory and fluid therapy as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, left lung collapse, and pericardial effusion. She has a history of unclear psychiatric illness, reported hypothyroidism, and is taking multiple medications, including anticonvulsants and antidepressants. She was intubated and sedated, and a transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) showed a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade. She was restarted on her outpatient medications, including those for bipolar disorder and hypothyroidism.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, blood pressure of 95/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Her respiratory support includes pressure support ventilation with a tidal volume of 360 mL and a respiratory rate of 12 inspirations per minute.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.3 K/uL, a hemoglobin level of 10.9 g/dL, and a platelet count of 214 K/uL. Her lactate level is elevated at 1.1 mmol/L, and her anion gap is 13.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and anion gap suggest hypoperfusion, which may be related to sepsis. The patient's pneumonia and pericardial effusion also increase her risk of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if her lung collapse or pneumonia is not properly managed.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's reported hypothyroidism may be contributing to her lethargy and altered mental status.
4. Psychiatric complications: The patient's unclear psychiatric history and medication regimen may increase her risk of psychiatric complications, such as delirium or agitation.
5. Pericardial effusion: The patient's moderate-sized pericardial effusion may require further evaluation and management to prevent complications such as tamponade.
6. Hypotension: The patient's borderline blood pressure and low urine output may indicate hypotension, which may be related to her sepsis, pneumonia, or pericardial effusion.
7. Medication-related complications: The patient's multiple medications, including anticonvulsants and antidepressants, may interact with each other or with other medications, leading to complications such as sedation or hypotension.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and left lung collapse. She has a history of unclear psychiatric illness and reported hypothyroidism. The patient was intubated and sedated, and a transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) showed a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade. She was treated with antibiotics for presumed community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and has been weaned off propofol sedation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, and blood pressure of 95/65 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2. She has a mild leukocytosis and an elevated anion gap. Her lactate level is elevated, but trending down.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bronchial breath sounds bilaterally, with no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Her abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended, with bowel sounds present. Her extremities are mildly cool, with 2+ pulses.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and anion gap suggest sepsis, which is a concern given her recent antibiotics and potential pneumonia.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's chest X-ray shows dense left lower lobe consolidation, which is consistent with pneumonia. The patient's respiratory failure may be secondary to mucous plugging from the pneumonia.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH level is markedly elevated, suggesting hypothyroidism. This may be contributing to her lethargy and altered mental status.
4. Overdose: The patient's positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone raises concern for overdose, which may be contributing to her lethargy and altered mental status.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's mild leukocytosis may be a response to the pneumonia or sepsis.
6. Pericardial effusion: The patient's small pericardial effusion may be a concern, especially given her recent antibiotics and potential sepsis.

Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics for presumed CAP.
2. Monitor the patient's lactate level and anion gap to assess for sepsis.
3. Reassess the patient's neuro status as wean sedation.
4. Restart the patient's home medications, including topiramate, divalproex, and seroquel.
5. Hold the patient's home clonazepam and zolpidem until further evaluation.
6. Consider switching to fentanyl and versed if the patient's hypotension persists.
7. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and urine output to assess for hypovolemia.
8. Consider adding a thyroid medication to treat the patient's hypothyroidism.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and recently presented to the emergency department with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was intubated and found to have left lung collapse.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: She is receiving pressure support ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50% and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular: Her blood pressure is 95/65 mmHg, and her heart rate is 92 beats per minute (bpm). Her peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2) is 100%.
* Renal function: Her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are within normal limits.
* Hematological: Her white blood cell count (WBC) is 11.3, and her platelet count is 214.
* Electrolytes: Her sodium, potassium, and chloride levels are within normal limits.
* Liver function: Her liver function tests (LFTs) are within normal limits.
* Thyroid function: Her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is markedly elevated, suggesting hypothyroidism.

The patient has been diagnosed with left lung collapse, likely secondary to mucous plugging from extensive consolidative pneumonia. She has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis: Given the patient's respiratory failure and pneumonia, there is a risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's elevated TSH level suggests hypothyroidism, which can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and cold intolerance.
* Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement since admission, which can lead to constipation and potentially serious complications such as bowel obstruction.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, which can be a sign of infection or inflammation.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which can be a sign of sepsis, hypovolemia, or medication side effects.
* Anion gap: The patient's anion gap is elevated, which can be a sign of metabolic acidosis or other electrolyte imbalances.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning off sedation and mechanical ventilation as tolerated
* Restarting her outpatient medications, including topiramate, divalproex, and levothyroxine
* Holding certain medications, including seroquel and clonazepam, due to concerns about medication interactions and overdose
* Reassessing her neuro status as sedation is weaned
* Repeating urine and blood cultures to monitor for infection
* Reassessing her respiratory status and adjusting her ventilator settings as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with hypoxic respiratory failure and left lung collapse. She has a history of unclear psychiatric issues and reported hypothyroidism. She was intubated and received broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient's condition has improved, with a small pericardial effusion noted on transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE). She has been weaned off propofol and is receiving pressure support ventilation. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and anion gap, but her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is markedly elevated.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may not be fully treated, and she may be at risk for further complications such as respiratory failure, sepsis, or organ failure.
2. Hypothyroidism: The patient's reported hypothyroidism may be contributing to her lethargy and altered mental status. Her TSH is markedly elevated, indicating hypothyroidism.
3. Pericardial effusion: Although the patient's pericardial effusion is small and not causing tamponade, it may still be a sign of underlying cardiac disease or infection.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate and anion gap may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ failure if not treated promptly.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may not be fully resolved, and she may be at risk for further respiratory complications.
6. Anion gap: The patient's anion gap is elevated, which may indicate metabolic acidosis or other underlying conditions.
7. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection or inflammation, which could lead to further complications if not treated.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, anesthesia, or other factors, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
9. Thyroid disorder: The patient's TSH is markedly elevated, indicating hypothyroidism, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
10. Increased lethargy/altered mental status: The patient's lethargy and altered mental status may be due to medication, infection, or other factors, and may require further evaluation and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected CAP.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation as needed.
3. Evaluate the patient's thyroid function and consider treatment for hypothyroidism.
4. Monitor the patient's lactate and anion gap levels and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Consider further evaluation and treatment for sepsis.
6. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Consider switching to fentanyl and versed if hypotension persists.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and adjust treatment as needed.
9. Consider further evaluation and treatment for anion gap.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch tall, 59.1 kg male who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), or aspiration with mucous plugging. He is currently on positive pressure ventilation (PSV) and has a tracheostomy tube in place. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. He has a pericardial effusion, but no evidence of tamponade, and is being treated with vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin for potential sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at high risk for VAP due to the presence of a tracheostomy tube and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and hypotension overnight suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could worsen if not treated promptly and aggressively.
3. Pericardial tamponade: Although the patient's pericardial effusion is not causing tamponade, it is still a significant finding that requires close monitoring.
4. Myxedema coma: The patient's profound hypothyroidism and obtundation raise concerns about the possibility of myxedema coma, which could be exacerbated by the patient's polypharmacy and sedative use.
5. Pneumonia progression: The patient's pneumonia could worsen if not treated effectively, leading to respiratory failure, sepsis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Aspiration: The patient's risk of aspiration is increased due to his tracheostomy tube and respiratory failure, which could lead to further respiratory compromise and pneumonia.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is positive, which could lead to fluid overload and worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
8. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's laboratory results show abnormal electrolyte levels, which could worsen if not addressed promptly and effectively.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and respiratory status closely.
2. Administer antibiotics as prescribed and reassess the patient's response.
3. Consider adding an anti-pseudomonal antibiotic to the patient's regimen to cover for potential Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection.
4. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust his fluid administration accordingly.
5. Consider adjusting the patient's sedation regimen to minimize the risk of respiratory depression and myxedema coma.
6. Monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and consider further imaging or intervention if necessary.
7. Consider adding an anticoagulant to the patient's regimen to prevent VAP.
8. Reassess the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his regimen as necessary to prevent further imbalances.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch tall, 59.1 kg individual with respiratory failure due to left lower lobe pneumonia. They have been intubated and are receiving positive pressure ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 91 beats per minute, blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on the ventilator.

The patient has a pericardial effusion noted on CT scan, but there is no evidence of tamponade on examination. They also have obtundation, which may be related to polypharmacy, a history of overdose, and profound hypothyroidism. The patient is receiving IV levothyroxine and has had their mood stabilizers resumed.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if they do not respond to treatment or if there is a delay in extubation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may progress or develop complications such as pleural effusion or empyema if not treated promptly and effectively.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and hypotension overnight suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not recognized and treated promptly.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may increase in size and cause cardiac tamponade if not monitored closely.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's profound hypothyroidism may worsen if not treated with IV levothyroxine, which could lead to further obtundation and other complications.
6. Polypharmacy: The patient's polypharmacy may increase the risk of adverse drug reactions, interactions, and complications if not monitored and managed carefully.
7. Overdose: The patient's history of overdose may increase the risk of further overdose or complications if not addressed and managed appropriately.
8. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen if not managed carefully, which could lead to respiratory and cardiovascular complications.

CT Head: No acute intracranial process. No hemorrhage. MRI is more sensitive for
 stroke.
   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Sputum cx now growing S. aureus sensitive to oxacillin. Partial
   re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent left mid-lung infiltrate.
   Increase in leukocytosis but no recent fevers.
   - continue zosyn
   - D/c levofloxacin and vancomycin
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily wake-up and SBT
   - will re bronch today to assess airway
   Leukocytosis: Pt remains afebrile; unclear why WBC cont to rise with
   variable left-shift. Currently treating pneumonia. Repeat U/A
   unremarkable; Ucx pending. Not on steroids. Ddx includes seizure.  Also
   of concern would be complicated pneumonia versus parapneumonia
   effusion.
   - Cont to trend WBC and temp curve
   - Abx as above pending sputum, blood, and urine cx data
   - Consider EEG
   Altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH with limited
   response off sedation. CT head negative. Likely hypothyroidism
   contributing with possibility of myxedema coma; h/o poor control. Given
   positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone, concern for
   overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related to known bipolar
   disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known seizure disorder.
   - Appreciate endo recs; given loading dose of levothyroxine 300mcg and
   to cont on 75mcg daily
   - Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel, clonazepam, and
   zolpidem for now
   - Consider EEG
   - Reassess neuro status daily off propofol
   Hypothyroidism: Poorly controlled with widely fluctuating TSH on review
   of past med records.
   - Cont levothyroxine 75mcg
   - F/u cortisol level to assess adrenal axis
   - F/u endo recs
   Bipolar disorder: Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel
   and clonazepam for now
   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of
   infection but MAPs stably above goal off pressors with likely
   contribution from used for sedation.
   - consider switching to fentanyl/versed if persistent hypotension
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Improved to 13 today. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
   and benzos. [**Month (only) 11**] have ketosis from poor po intake.
   - Cont maintenance fluids
   - holding tube feeds pending bronchoscopy but will restart afterwards
   Pericardial effusion: Small without evidence of tamponade on TTE.
   Constipation: No BM since admit
   - Increase bowel regimen prn
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding tube feeds for now for bronchoscopy but will restart
   this afternoon
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2167-6-9**] 11:59 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:

   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was intubated and found to have left lung collapse.

The patient has a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and poorly controlled thyroid levels. She was found to have a TSH of 54 and a free T4 level of <0.10, which is consistent with hypothyroidism. She was given a loading dose of levothyroxine 300mcg and is currently receiving 75mcg daily.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a partial re-expansion of the left lung after bronchoscopy and a persistent left mid-lung infiltrate. The sputum culture is growing Staphylococcus aureus, which is sensitive to oxacillin. The patient is being treated with Zosyn, and the antibiotic regimen will be adjusted based on the results of the sputum and blood cultures.

The patient's leukocytosis is concerning, with a WBC count of 23.5 K/uL. The differential is not provided, but the patient is not febrile. The patient is being treated for pneumonia, and the differential diagnosis includes complicated pneumonia versus parapneumonic effusion.

The patient's mental status is also concerning, with altered mental status and a TSH of 54. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder, and the possibility of myxedema coma is being considered. The patient is being treated with levothyroxine, and an EEG is being considered to rule out seizure activity.

The patient's hypothyroidism is poorly controlled, with a TSH of 54 and a free T4 level of <0.10. The patient is being treated with levothyroxine, and a cortisol level is being obtained to assess the adrenal axis.

The patient's anion gap is improved, but the lactate level is still elevated. The patient's tox screens are positive only for methadone and benzodiazepines, and the possibility of ketosis from poor PO intake is being considered.

The patient's pericardial effusion is small and not causing tamponade. The patient is constipated and is being treated with a bowel regimen.

The patient's ICU care is being managed with a focus on respiratory support, nutrition, and glycemic control. The patient is being treated with antibiotics for pneumonia, and the antibiotic regimen will be adjusted based on the results of the sputum and blood cultures.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or parapneumonic effusion
* Seizure activity due to hypothyroidism or medication toxicity
* Myxedema coma due to untreated hypothyroidism
* Infection due to the presence of a pericardial effusion
* Constipation and bowel obstruction due to poor nutrition and medication
* Hypotension due to sepsis or medication toxicity
* Anion gap acidosis due to poor PO intake or medication toxicity

It is essential to continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status, mental status, and thyroid function, as well as to adjust the antibiotic regimen based on the results of the sputum and blood cultures. The patient's bowel regimen should be continued to manage constipation, and the patient's nutrition should be re-evaluated to ensure adequate intake.

TEXT:

CT Head: No acute intracranial process. No hemorrhage. MRI is more sensitive for
 stroke.
   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Sputum cx now growing S. aureus, sensitivies pending. Partial
   re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent left mid-lung infiltrate.
   Increase in leukocytosis.
   - Cont vanc, zosyn pending final cx results
   - D/c levofloxacin
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily wake-up and SBT
   Leukocytosis: Pt remains afebrile; unclear why WBC cont to rise with
   variable left-shift. Currently treating pneumonia. Repeat U/A
   unremarkable; Ucx pending. Not on steroids. Ddx includes seizure.
   - Cont to trend WBC and temp curve
   - Abx as above pending sputum, blood, and urine cx data
   - Consider EEG
   Altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH with limited
   response off sedation. CT head negative. Likely hypothyroidism
   contributing with possibility of myxedema coma; h/o poor control. Given
   positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone, concern for
   overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related to known bipolar
   disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known seizure disorder.
   - Appreciate endo recs; given loading dose of levothyroxine 300mcg and
   to cont on 75mcg daily
   - Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel, clonazepam, and
   zolpidem for now
   - Consider EEG
   - Reassess neuro status daily off propofol
   Hypothyroidism: Poorly controlled with widely fluctuating TSH on review
   of past med records.
   - Cont levothyroxine 75mcg
   - F/u cortisol level to assess adrenal axis
   - F/u endo recs
   Bipolar disorder: Cont home topiramate, divalproex; holding seroquel
   and clonazepam for now
   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of
   infection but MAPs stably above goal off pressors with likely
   contribution from used for sedation.
   - consider switching to fentanyl/versed if persistent hypotension
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Improved to 13 today. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
   and benzos. [**Month (only) 11**] have ketosis from poor po intake.
   - Cont maintenance fluids and tube feeds
   Pericardial effusion: Small without evidence of tamponade on TTE.
   Constipation: No BM since admit
   - Increase bowel regimen prn
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Holding tube feeds for now for possible extubation
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2167-6-9**] 11:59 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and poorly controlled thyroid function. She was admitted to the ICU with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is mechanically ventilated with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 607 mL, a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and an FiO2 of 40%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is stable, with a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 100 mmHg, and a heart rate of 96 beats per minute.
* Neurological: The patient is still not responsive to noxious stimuli, but has a normal electroencephalogram (EEG).
* Endocrine: The patient has been diagnosed with hypothyroidism, and is receiving treatment with levothyroxine.
* Infection: The patient has a positive sputum culture for Staphylococcus aureus, and is being treated with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has been experiencing constipation since admission, and is being treated with a bowel regimen.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's sputum culture is positive for Staphylococcus aureus, and she is at risk for developing pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient's infection and inflammatory response may lead to sepsis, which can cause organ dysfunction and failure.
* Myxedema coma: The patient's hypothyroidism and altered mental status may be contributing to her current condition, and she is at risk for developing myxedema coma.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol level is pending, and she is at risk for developing adrenal insufficiency.
* Constipation: The patient's constipation may lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, or other complications.
* Pneumothorax: The patient's left lung collapse may lead to pneumothorax, which can cause respiratory distress and failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for pneumonia
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and organ dysfunction
* Adjusting thyroid hormone replacement therapy as needed
* Managing constipation with a bowel regimen
* Weaning from mechanical ventilation as tolerated
* Monitoring for signs of myxedema coma and adrenal insufficiency
* Reassessing neuro status daily off propofol

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch tall, 59.1 kg individual who was admitted to the ICU with a history of thyroid abuse for weight loss and stopping abruptly, leading to a TSH of 150 in the past. The patient was weaned off sedation, but remained unresponsive to stimuli other than noxious stimuli. Sputum culture showed moderate Staph aureus growth. Endocrine consult recommended treating the patient as if in frank myxedema coma, with IV levothyroxine and daily cortisol checks. The patient has a history of psychiatric disease, including schizophrenia and personality disorders.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), heart rate of 96 bpm, blood pressure of 100/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on CPAP/PSV ventilation with a FiO2 of 40%. The patient's physical examination is limited due to their unresponsiveness.

Laboratory results show elevated WBC count, leukocytosis, and abnormal thyroid function tests. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits. The patient has a pericardial effusion without tamponade and hypotension.

Potential medical complications:

1. Infection: The patient's sputum culture shows moderate Staph aureus growth, which may lead to a pulmonary infection.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and their ABG results show a pH of 7.15, which may indicate respiratory failure.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function tests are abnormal, which may lead to complications such as myxedema coma.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion without tamponade may lead to cardiac tamponade if left untreated.
5. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may lead to organ dysfunction if left untreated.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's elevated WBC count may indicate an underlying infection or inflammatory process.
7. Psychiatric complications: The patient's history of psychiatric disease, including schizophrenia and personality disorders, may lead to complications such as agitation, delirium, or psychosis.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's nutritional status is unknown, and they may be at risk for malnutrition or dehydration if not properly managed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy for the patient's pulmonary infection.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
3. Continue thyroid replacement therapy and monitor the patient's thyroid function tests.
4. Monitor the patient's pericardial effusion and consider drainage or pericardiocentesis if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider vasopressor therapy if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's WBC count and consider antibiotics if the patient develops an infection.
7. Consider psychiatric consultation to manage the patient's psychiatric symptoms.
8. Consider nutritional support to ensure the patient's nutritional needs are met.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch, 59.1 kg individual who was admitted to the ICU with a history of abusing thyroid medication for weight loss and stopping abruptly, resulting in a TSH of 150 in the past. The patient has been treated for suspected myxedema coma, with boluses of IV levothyroxine and daily dosing of 75 mcg IV.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* The patient remains intubated and not responsive to noxious stimuli, with a TSH of 54 and Free T4 <0.10.
* The patient has a pericardial effusion, which is being treated.
* The patient has leukocytosis, with a WBC count of 23.5 K/uL.
* The patient has respiratory failure, with a RSBI of 32 and an ABG of 7.15.
* The patient has hypothyroidism, which is being treated with levothyroxine.
* The patient has a history of psychiatric disease, including schizophrenia and personality disorders.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Worsening of hypothyroidism, leading to further decline in cardiac function and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
* Development of thyroid storm, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, hypertension, and respiratory failure.
* Progression of pericardial effusion, leading to cardiac tamponade and decreased cardiac output.
* Respiratory failure, which can lead to further decline in oxygenation and increased risk of pneumonia.
* Leukocytosis, which can lead to increased risk of infection and sepsis.
* Hypotension, which can lead to decreased cardiac output and decreased perfusion of vital organs.

The patient's care plan should include:

* Continued treatment of hypothyroidism with levothyroxine.
* Monitoring of the patient's cardiac function and pericardial effusion.
* Management of respiratory failure with continued mechanical ventilation and optimization of oxygenation.
* Monitoring of the patient's leukocytosis and treatment of any associated infections.
* Management of hypotension with vasopressors and fluid management.
* Close monitoring of the patient's overall condition and adjustments to the care plan as needed.

[**2167-6-10**] 1:08 am SPUTUM      Source: Endotracheal.
   GRAM STAIN (Final [**2167-6-10**]):
      >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.
      3+  (5-10 per 1000X FIELD):   MULTIPLE ORGANISMS CONSISTENT WITH
                                    OROPHARYNGEAL FLORA.
   RESPIRATORY CULTURE (Preliminary):
      SPARSE GROWTH OROPHARYNGEAL FLORA.
      STAPH AUREUS COAG +.    MODERATE GROWTH.
   Assessment and Plan
   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Likely CAP v. aspiration; less likely HAP.  Urine legionella Ag neg.
   Favor broad antibiotic coverage at this time pending further micro and
   clinical history data.  Partial re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent
   left mid-lung infiltrate. Increase in leukocytosis.
   - Cont vanc, zosyn, levofloxacin for broad empiric coverage
   - F/u sputum and blood cultures
   - Wean vent as tolerated with daily RSBI/SBT
   - Wean sedation as tolerated
   Leukocytosis: Increased today. Currently treating pneumonia with broad
   abx. U/A on admit inconclusive for infection. Not on steroids.
   - Add differential
   - Recheck U/A with Ucx; check C. diff
   - Cont above abx
   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of
   infection; may have contribution from propofol used for sedation. Did
   not require pressors. Currently stable on maintenance fluids with
   improved UOP.
   - consider switching to fentanyl/versed if persistent hypotension
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Elevated at 15. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
   and benzos. [**Month (only) 11**] have ketosis from poor po intake.
   - Check lactate with next ABG
   - Recheck U/A
   - Cont maintenance fluids and tube feeds
   Pericardial effusion: Small without evidence of tamponade on TTE.
   Thyroid disorder: Per OSH report, may have hypothyroidism; rx for
   armourthyroid last filled in [**12-12**]. Unclear if pt taking medications for
   this. TSH markedly elevated.
   - Check free T4
   - start levothyroxine IV
   Constipation: No BM since admit
   - increase bowel regimen
   Increased lethargy/altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH.
   Given positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone also
   concerning for overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related
   to known bipolar disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known
   seizure disorder.
   - likely hypothyroidism contributing
   - Reassess neuro status as wean sedation
   - Restarted on home topiramate, divalproex,
   - Hold seroquel for now
   - Holding home clonazepam while on sedation
   - Holding home zolpidem
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2167-6-9**] 11:59 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2167-6-10**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and a recent presentation to the emergency department with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure. She was intubated and found to have left lung collapse, likely due to mucous plugging from extensive consolidative pneumonia. She has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and levofloxacin. She has also been diagnosed with pericardial effusion, thyroid disorder, and constipation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require ongoing mechanical ventilation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely to be severe and may require additional antibiotics or other treatments.
3. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may require further evaluation and treatment, including pericardiocentesis or surgery.
4. Thyroid disorder: The patient's thyroid disorder may require further evaluation and treatment, including thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
5. Constipation: The patient's constipation may require additional treatment, including laxatives or stool softeners.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of an underlying infection or inflammation, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to sepsis, and may require additional treatment, including vasopressors or fluids.
8. Anion gap: The patient's anion gap is elevated, which may indicate an underlying metabolic disorder or electrolyte imbalance, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
9. Lactate elevation: The patient's lactate elevation may indicate an underlying metabolic disorder or tissue hypoperfusion, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
10. Neurological status: The patient's neurological status is altered, and may require further evaluation and treatment, including neuroimaging studies or electroencephalography.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
3. Continue thyroid hormone replacement therapy as prescribed.
4. Manage the patient's constipation with laxatives or stool softeners.
5. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's hypotension and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's anion gap and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's lactate elevation and adjust treatment as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
10. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's pericardial effusion and thyroid disorder.

   43 yo female with h/o bipolar d/o, hypothyroidism who presented to OSH
   with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation and found to have left lung collapse.
   Respiratory failure: Left lung white-out on chest imaging c/w left lung
   atelectasis/collapse. Likely secondary to mucous plugging from
   extensive consolidative pneumonia. No obstructive lesion on bronch.
   Likely CAP v. aspiration; less likely HAP.  Urine legionella Ag neg.
   Favor broad antibiotic coverage at this time pending further micro and
   clinical history data.  Partial re-expansion s/p bronch with persistent
   left mid-lung infiltrate. Increase in leukocytosis.

   Hypotension: Baseline unknown. Concern for sepsis in setting of

   - increase bowel regimen

   Given positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone also

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and is currently being treated for pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 607 mL. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 40%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg, and her heart rate is 96 beats per minute.
* Neurological status: The patient is not responsive to verbal stimuli, but does respond to noxious stimuli. Her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is not specified.
* Renal status: The patient's urine output is 2,705 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Hematological status: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated at 23.5 K/uL, and her platelet count is 73 K/uL.
* Endocrine status: The patient's thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is markedly elevated at 54, and her free thyroxine (FT4) level is less than 0.10. The patient has a history of abusing thyroid medication for weight loss and stopping abruptly, which may have contributed to her current thyroid status.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and positive culture results suggest that she may be at risk for developing sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute may put her at risk for developing respiratory failure.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's elevated TSH and low FT4 levels suggest that she may have hypothyroidism, which may require further treatment.
* Pericardial effusion: The patient's small pericardial effusion may require further monitoring and treatment.
* Constipation: The patient's lack of bowel movement since admission may require further treatment and monitoring.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions that require close monitoring and treatment. The patient's respiratory status, neurological status, and endocrine status all require close attention, and the patient may be at risk for developing various medical complications.

   infection; may have contribution from propofol used for sedation. Did
   not require pressors. Currently stable on maintenance fluids with
   improved UOP.
   - consider switching to fentanyl/versed if persistent hypotension
   - antibiotics as above for pneumonia
   - goal MAP >60, UOP >30 cc/h
   Anion gap: Elevated at 15. Lactate elevated on admission but had
   trended down when rechecked. Tox screens positive only for methadone
   and benzos. [**Month (only) 11**] have ketosis from poor po intake.
   - Check lactate with next ABG
   - Recheck U/A
   - Cont maintenance fluids and tube feeds
   Pericardial effusion: Small without evidence of tamponade on TTE.
   Thyroid disorder: Per OSH report, may have hypothyroidism; rx for
   armourthyroid last filled in [**12-12**]. Unclear if pt taking medications for
   this. TSH markedly elevated.
   - Check free T4
   - start levothyroxine IV
   Constipation: No BM since admit
   - increase bowel regimen
   Increased lethargy/altered mental status: Presenting complaint to OSH.
   Given positive toxicology screen for opiates and methadone also
   concerning for overdose versus medication effect. [**Month (only) 11**] also be related
   to known bipolar disorder, reportedly poorly controlled. No known
   seizure disorder.
   - likely hypothyroidism contributing
   - Reassess neuro status as wean sedation
   - Restarted on home topiramate, divalproex,
   - Hold seroquel for now
   - Holding home clonazepam while on sedation
   - Holding home zolpidem

Summary:

The patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and thyroid medication non-adherence. She presented to the hospital with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. She was found to have left lung collapse and consolidative pneumonia. She was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and has been weaned from sedation. Her WBC count is elevated, and she has a TSH level of 54 with a free T4 level <0.10. She was started on IV levothyroxine and has a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and she has a history of pneumonia, which increases her risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to mucous plugging from consolidative pneumonia, which may worsen if not managed properly.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH level is elevated, and she has a history of hypothyroidism, which may contribute to her lethargy and altered mental status.
4. Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement since admission, which may worsen if not managed properly.
5. Anion gap: The patient's anion gap is elevated, which may indicate a metabolic acidosis.
6. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a small pericardial effusion without evidence of tamponade, which may worsen if not managed properly.
7. Thyroid crisis: The patient's TSH level is elevated, and she has a history of thyroid medication non-adherence, which may increase her risk of developing a thyroid crisis.
8. Overdose: The patient's toxicology screen is positive for opiates and methadone, which may indicate an overdose.
9. Bipolar disorder: The patient has a history of bipolar disorder, which may contribute to her altered mental status and lethargy.
10. Infection: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and she has a history of pneumonia, which increases her risk of developing an infection.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall individual weighing 59.1 kg, admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely caused by community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), or aspiration with mucous plugging. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 541 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 11 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.1°C, heart rate of 98 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 95/70 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 23 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (23.5 K/uL), hemoglobin (10.0 g/dL), and lactate (1.1 mmol/L). The patient's blood cultures are pending, and the microbiology results show MSSA and GPCs in the sputum sample.

The patient's imaging studies, including a computed tomography (CT) head and chest X-ray, are negative for acute processes. The patient's pericardial effusion is noted on the CT scan, but there is no evidence of pulsus on exam.

The patient's medication list includes levothyroxine, depakote, topamax, synthroid IV, colace, heparin sodium, famotidine, and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient is also receiving IV fluids and has a nasogastric tube in place.

The patient's plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, broad antibiotic coverage, and close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results. The patient's sedation will be continued, and the possibility of extubation will be assessed later today or tomorrow. The patient's family will be updated on the patient's condition and plan.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and hypotension overnight suggest the possibility of sepsis. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if the patient's lung function does not improve. Close monitoring of the patient's oxygen saturation and respiratory rate is necessary to detect any signs of respiratory failure.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen if the patient's antibiotic coverage is inadequate. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of worsening pneumonia.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion may worsen if the patient's cardiac function does not improve. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and electrocardiogram is necessary to detect any signs of worsening pericardial effusion.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection or inflammation. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of infection or inflammation.
6. C. difficile colitis: The patient's leukocytosis and abdominal symptoms may be a sign of C. difficile colitis. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of C. difficile colitis.
7. Empyema: The patient's leukocytosis and chest symptoms may be a sign of empyema. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of empyema.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple potential medical complications. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results is necessary to detect any signs of worsening medical conditions.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall, 59.1 kg individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to LLL pneumonia. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and steroids.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.1°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 95/70 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99% on 40% FiO2, and they are receiving CPAP/PSV ventilation with a respiratory rate of 23 inspirations per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and creatinine levels. The patient's chest X-ray shows LUL and LLL atelectasis, and their CT head is negative for acute process.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), or aspiration with mucous plugging. The patient will continue to receive PSV ventilation and will be assessed for possible extubation later today or tomorrow.
2. Possible sepsis: The patient is hypotensive with elevated lactate levels, and their white blood cell count is elevated. The patient will continue to receive fluid resuscitation targeted to urine output and blood pressure, and antibiotics will be continued.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient will be checked for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection, and a low threshold will be used to rescan the chest for empyema.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a pericardial effusion noted on CT scan, but there is no evidence of tamponade on examination. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) without tamponade evidence was performed.
5. Obtundation: The patient is obtunded due to polypharmacy, including the use of mood stabilizers, sedatives, and profound hypothyroidism. The patient will receive IV levothyroxine and will have their mood stabilizers and sedatives held.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure can progress to more severe respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient's possible sepsis can progress to more severe sepsis, including septic shock.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis can progress to neutropenia, which can increase the risk of infection.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion can progress to cardiac tamponade, which can be life-threatening.
5. Obtundation: The patient's obtundation can progress to coma or even death.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications and improve their outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current health status as follows:

The patient is a 43-year-old female with a history of bipolar disorder, hypothyroidism, and poorly controlled thyroid levels. She was admitted to the hospital with increased lethargy and hypoxemic respiratory failure, requiring intubation. The patient has a diagnosis of left lung collapse with extensive consolidative pneumonia, likely caused by mucous plugging from MSSA-positive sputum cultures.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.8°F (38.8°C)
* Heart rate: 99 bpm
* Blood pressure: 104/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 31 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 493 mL and a respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute. The patient's blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.11, pCO2 of 11 mmHg, and pO2 of 55 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 14.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 246 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Albumin: 3.2 g/dL
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.0 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) for pneumonia
* Propofol for sedation
* Famotidine (Pepcid) for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin sodium for prophylaxis

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Complicated pneumonia or parapneumonic effusion
* Sepsis
* Myxedema coma due to hypothyroidism
* Overdose or medication effect due to toxicology screen results
* Hypotension
* Anion gap metabolic acidosis
* Constipation
* Pericardial effusion
* VAP (ventilator-associated pneumonia)

Based on the patient's current condition and laboratory results, I recommend the following:

* Continue antibiotics for pneumonia
* Monitor the patient's temperature and white blood cell count trend
* Consider EEG to rule out seizure disorder
* Reassess neuro status daily off propofol
* Continue levothyroxine 75 mcg daily for hypothyroidism
* Follow up with endocrinology for further recommendations
* Hold tube feeds pending bronchoscopy and restart afterwards
* Increase bowel regimen for constipation
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust treatment accordingly.
